news_summary: Advances in AI, natural viruses, and bio-inspired technologies are rapidly enhancing cancer treatments, pain relief, and medical device innovation.
news_summary_fr: Les progrès de l'IA, des virus naturels et des technologies bio-inspirées améliorent rapidement les traitements contre le cancer, le soulagement de la douleur et l'innovation en matière de dispositifs médicaux.
news_summary_es: Los avances en IA, virus naturales y tecnologías bioinspiradas están mejorando rápidamente los tratamientos contra el cáncer, el alivio del dolor y la innovación en dispositivos médicos.

articles.title: AI turns immune cells into precision cancer killers—in just weeks
articles.summary: A breakthrough AI system is revolutionizing cancer immunotherapy by enabling scientists to design protein-based keys that train a patient s immune cells to attack cancer with extreme precision. This method, capable of reducing development time from years to weeks, was successfully tested on known and patient-specific tumor targets. Using virtual safety screenings to avoid harmful side effects, the platform represents a leap forward in personalized medicine.
articles.content:
Precision cancer treatment on a larger scale is moving closer after researchers have developed an AI platform that can tailor protein components and arm the patient's immune cells to fight cancer. The new method, published in the scientific journal Science, demonstrates for the first time, that it is possible to design proteins in the computer for redirecting immune cells to target cancer cells through pMHC molecules.

This dramatically shortens the process of finding effective molecules for cancer treatment from years to a few weeks.

"We are essentially creating a new set of eyes for the immune system. Current methods for individual cancer treatment are based on finding so-called T-cell receptors in the immune system of a patient or donor that can be used for treatment. This is a very time-consuming and challenging process. Our platform designs molecular keys to target cancer cells using the AI platform, and it does so at incredible speed, so that a new lead molecule can be ready within 4-6 weeks," says Associate Professor at the Technical University of Denmark (DTU) and last author of the study Timothy P. Jenkins.

Targeted missiles against cancer

The AI platform, developed by a team from DTU and the American Scripps Research Institute, aims to solve a major challenge in cancer immunotherapy by demonstrating how scientists can generate target treatments for tumor cells and avoid damaging healthy tissue.

Normally, T cells naturally identify cancer cells by recognizing specific protein fragments, known as peptides, presented on the cell surface by molecules called pMHCs.It is a slow and challenging process to utilize this knowledge for therapy, often because the variation in the body's own T-cell receptors makes it challenging to create a personalized treatment.

Boosting the body's immune system

In the study, the researchers tested the strength of the AI platform on a well-known cancer target, NY-ESO-1, which is found in a wide range of cancers. The team succeeded in designing a minibinder that bound tightly to the NY-ESO-1 pMHC molecules. When the designed protein was inserted into T cells, it created a unique new cell product named 'IMPAC-T' cells by the researchers, which effectively guided the T cells to kill cancer cells in laboratory experiments.

"It was incredibly exciting to take these minibinders, which were created entirely on a computer, and see them work so effectively in the laboratory," says postdoc Kristoffer Haurum Johansen, co-author of the study and researcher at DTU.

The researchers also applied the pipeline to design binders for a cancer target identified in a metastatic melanoma patient, successfully generating binders for this target as well. This documented that the method also can be used for tailored immunotherapy against novel cancer targets.

Screening of treatments

A crucial step in the researchers' innovation was the development of a 'virtual safety check'. The team used AI to screen their designed minibinders and assess them in relation to pMHC molecules found on healthy cells. This method enabled them to filter out minibinders that could cause dangerous side effects before any experiments were carried out.

"Precision in cancer treatment is crucial. By predicting and ruling out cross-reactions already in the design phase, we were able to reduce the risk associated with the designed proteins and increase the likelihood of designing a safe and effective therapy," says DTU professor and co-author of the study Sine Reker Hadrup.

Five years to treatment

Timothy Patrick Jenkins expects that it will take up to five years before the new method is ready for initial clinical trials in humans. Once the method is ready, the treatment process will resemble current cancer treatments using genetically modified T cells, known as CAR-T cells, which are currently used to treat lymphoma and leukemia.Patients will first have blood drawn at the hospital, similar to a routine blood test. Their immune cells will then be extracted from this blood sample and modified in the laboratory to carry the AI-designed minibinders. These enhanced immune cells are returned to the patient, where they act like targeted missiles, precisely finding and eliminating cancer cells in the body.
articles.reasoning: The article describes a significant scientific breakthrough in cancer immunotherapy using AI, which drastically reduces development time and enhances precision, representing a major advance in personalized medicine and offering hope to cancer patients.
articles.personality_title: AI helps immune cells become precise cancer fighters in weeks
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context**
Scientists have been working for years to improve cancer immunotherapy, a treatment that trains the body’s immune cells to attack cancer. Traditionally, designing the right proteins to guide immune cells took years, slowing down personalized treatment options.

**What happened**
Researchers created an AI system that designs special proteins, called pMHC molecules, on a computer. These proteins help the patient’s immune cells recognize and target cancer cells with great accuracy. This approach was tested successfully on both common and patient-specific tumor targets. The AI also checks for safety virtually to avoid harmful side effects.

**Impact**
This breakthrough cuts the time to develop personalized cancer treatments from years to just weeks. It allows doctors to quickly create tailored therapies that train the immune system to fight cancer more precisely, increasing hope for better outcomes with fewer side effects.

**What's next step**
The team plans to expand testing of this AI-designed treatment in clinical trials and explore its use with different types of cancer. If successful, this approach could become a new standard for personalized cancer immunotherapy worldwide.

**One-sentence takeaway**
AI is revolutionizing cancer treatment by rapidly creating precise immune cell trainers, offering faster, safer, and personalized hope to patients.
articles.personality_title_fr: L'IA transforme les cellules immunitaires en guerriers précis contre le cancer en quelques semaines
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte**
Les scientifiques travaillent depuis des années à améliorer l'immunothérapie contre le cancer, un traitement qui apprend aux cellules immunitaires du corps à attaquer le cancer. Habituellement, concevoir les bonnes protéines pour guider ces cellules prenait des années, ralentissant les options de traitement personnalisées.

**Ce qui s'est passé**
Des chercheurs ont créé un système d'IA qui conçoit des protéines spéciales, appelées molécules pMHC, sur ordinateur. Ces protéines aident les cellules immunitaires du patient à reconnaître et cibler les cellules cancéreuses avec une grande précision. Cette méthode a été testée avec succès sur des tumeurs courantes et spécifiques à chaque patient. L'IA vérifie aussi la sécurité virtuellement pour éviter les effets secondaires dangereux.

**Impact**
Cette avancée réduit le temps de développement des traitements personnalisés contre le cancer de plusieurs années à quelques semaines seulement. Elle permet aux médecins de créer rapidement des thérapies sur mesure qui entraînent le système immunitaire à combattre le cancer plus précisément, augmentant les chances de meilleurs résultats avec moins d'effets secondaires.

**Quelle est la prochaine étape**
L'équipe prévoit d'élargir les tests de ce traitement conçu par IA dans des essais cliniques et d'explorer son utilisation pour différents types de cancers. Si cela fonctionne, cette méthode pourrait devenir un nouveau standard pour l'immunothérapie personnalisée contre le cancer dans le monde.

**À retenir en une phrase**
L'IA révolutionne le traitement du cancer en créant rapidement des entraîneurs précis des cellules immunitaires, offrant un espoir plus rapide, plus sûr et personnalisé aux patients.
articles.personality_title_es: La IA convierte células inmunitarias en asesinos precisos del cáncer en semanas
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto**
Los científicos han trabajado durante años para mejorar la inmunoterapia contra el cáncer, un tratamiento que enseña a las células inmunitarias del cuerpo a atacar el cáncer. Tradicionalmente, diseñar las proteínas adecuadas para guiar estas células tomaba años, retrasando las opciones de tratamiento personalizado.

**Qué pasó**
Investigadores crearon un sistema de IA que diseña proteínas especiales, llamadas moléculas pMHC, en una computadora. Estas proteínas ayudan a las células inmunitarias del paciente a reconocer y atacar las células cancerosas con gran precisión. Este método se probó con éxito en tumores comunes y específicos de cada paciente. La IA también realiza controles de seguridad virtuales para evitar efectos secundarios dañinos.

**Impacto**
Este avance reduce el tiempo de desarrollo de tratamientos personalizados contra el cáncer de años a solo semanas. Permite a los médicos crear rápidamente terapias hechas a medida que entrenan al sistema inmunológico para combatir el cáncer con más precisión, aumentando las esperanzas de mejores resultados con menos efectos secundarios.

**Cuál es el siguiente paso**
El equipo planea ampliar las pruebas de este tratamiento diseñado por IA en ensayos clínicos y explorar su uso con diferentes tipos de cáncer. Si tiene éxito, este enfoque podría convertirse en un nuevo estándar para la inmunoterapia personalizada contra el cáncer en todo el mundo.

**Frase clave**
La IA está revolucionando el tratamiento del cáncer al crear rápidamente entrenadores precisos para las células inmunitarias, ofreciendo esperanza más rápida, segura y personalizada a los pacientes.
articles.image_prompt: A detailed, warm painting of glowing, intricately shaped keys unlocking vibrant, shielded cells resembling immune cells depicted as gentle warriors, targeting and surrounding stylized cancer cells portrayed as dark, irregular clusters, all set against a soft, natural-hued background symbolizing a hopeful, precise medical breakthrough.

articles.title: The plant virus that trains your immune system to kill cancer
articles.summary: A virus from humble black-eyed peas is showing extraordinary promise in the fight against cancer. Unlike other plant viruses, the cowpea mosaic virus (CPMV) can awaken the human immune system and transform it into a cancer-fighting powerhouse, without infecting human cells. By comparing it to a similar, but ineffective, virus, researchers uncovered that CPMV uniquely triggers potent interferons and immune responses, making it a low-cost, plant-grown immunotherapy on the fast track toward clinical trials.
articles.content:
A virus that typically infects black-eyed peas is showing great promise as a low-cost, potent cancer immunotherapy -- and researchers are uncovering why.

In a study published in Cell Biomaterials, a team led by chemical and nano engineers at the University of California San Diego took a closer look at how the cowpea mosaic virus (CPMV), unlike other plant viruses, is uniquely effective at activating the body's immune system to recognize and attack cancer cells.

In preclinical studies, CPMV has demonstrated potent anti-tumor effects in multiple mouse models, as well as in canine cancer patients. When injected directly into tumors, CPMV therapy recruits innate immune cells -- such as neutrophils, macrophages and natural killer cells -- into the tumor microenvironment to destroy cancer cells. Meanwhile, it activates B cells and T cells to establish systemic, long-lasting anti-tumor memory. This immune reawakening not only helps clear the targeted tumor but also primes the immune system to hunt down metastatic tumors elsewhere in the body.

"It is fascinating that CPMV but not other plant viruses stimulates an anti-tumor response," said Nicole Steinmetz, the Leo and Trude Szilard Chancellor's Endowed Chair in the Aiiso Yufeng Li Family Department of Chemical and Nano Engineering at the UC San Diego Jacobs School of Engineering and the study's corresponding author.

"This work gives us insight into how CPMV works so well," said study first author Anthony Omole, a chemical and nano engineering Ph.D. student in Steinmetz's lab. "What we found most exciting is that although human immune cells are not infected by CPMV, they respond to it and are reprogrammed towards an activated state, which ultimately trains them to detect and eradicate cancerous cells."

A key question in translating CPMV to human cancer patients has been: what makes this plant virus so effective at fighting cancer?

To investigate, Omole, Steinmetz and colleagues at the National Cancer Institute's ​​Nanotechnology Characterization Laboratory performed a side-by-side comparison of CPMV with the cowpea chlorotic mottle virus (CCMV), a closely related plant virus that does not exhibit anti-tumor effects when administered intratumorally. Both viruses form similarly sized nanoparticles and are taken up by human immune cells at similar rates. Yet, once inside, the viruses produce different outcomes.

CPMV, the team found, stimulates type I, II and III interferons -- proteins with well-known anti-cancer properties. "This is particularly interesting because some of the earliest cancer immunotherapy drugs were recombinant interferons," noted Omole. Meanwhile, CCMV stimulates a set of pro-inflammatory interleukins that do not translate to effective tumor clearance. Another difference lies in how these viruses' RNAs are processed within mammalian cells. CPMV RNAs persist longer and get delivered to the endolysosome, where they activate toll-like receptor 7 (TLR7), a critical component in priming antiviral -- and more importantly -- anti-tumor immune responses. CCMV RNAs, on the other hand, fail to reach this activation point.

CPMV also offers a unique advantage as a cost-effective immunotherapy. Unlike many other therapies that require complex and costly manufacturing, CPMV can be produced using molecular farming. "It can be grown in plants using sunlight, soil and water," Omole said.

The team is working toward advancing CPMV to clinical trials.

"The present study provides important insights into the mechanism of action of CPMV. We are diligently working toward the next steps to ensure that the most potent lead candidate is selected to achieve anti-tumor efficacy and safety," Steinmetz said. "This is the time and we are poised to move this work beyond the bench and toward clinical trials."

This work was supported in part by the National Institutes of Health (NIH grants R01 CA224605, R01 CA253615 and R01 CA274640); the American Cancer Society, F.M. Kirby Foundation Inc., Mission Boost Grant (MBGI-23-1030244-01-MBG); the Shaughnessy Family Fund for Nano-ImmunoEngineering (nanoIE) at UC San Diego; San Diego Fellowship Fund; the Alfred P. Sloan Foundation's Minority PhD (MPhD) Program (G-2020-14067); and the Frederick National Laboratory for Cancer Research funded by the National Cancer Institute, part of the NIH (under contract 75N91010D00024).
articles.reasoning: The article describes a promising scientific breakthrough where a plant virus can stimulate the human immune system to fight cancer effectively. This advancement offers hope for a low-cost, accessible cancer immunotherapy, which is a significant positive development in medical research and patient care.
articles.personality_title: A plant virus trains your immune system to fight cancer
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context**
Scientists have discovered that a virus from black-eyed peas, called the cowpea mosaic virus (CPMV), can activate the human immune system to attack cancer cells. Unlike many viruses, CPMV does not infect human cells but still manages to wake up the body's defenses.

**What happened**
Researchers at the University of California San Diego studied CPMV and found it triggers strong immune responses, especially by producing interferons—proteins that help organize the attack on tumors. They compared CPMV to similar plant viruses that don’t have this effect, uncovering what makes CPMV special. This understanding helps explain why CPMV can act as a powerful, low-cost immunotherapy.

**Impact**
This discovery means we could have an affordable treatment that uses a natural plant virus to boost the body’s own cancer-fighting abilities. Since CPMV is grown in plants and safely stimulates immunity without infection, it offers hope for wider access to cancer immunotherapy, especially in places where expensive treatments are hard to get.

**What's next step**
Researchers plan to move CPMV-based treatments into clinical trials to test their safety and effectiveness in humans. If successful, this could lead to new, affordable cancer therapies becoming available soon.

**One-sentence takeaway**
A virus from black-eyed peas is unlocking the immune system’s power to fight cancer, promising a low-cost and effective treatment option.
articles.personality_title_fr: Un virus végétal entraîne votre système immunitaire à combattre le cancer
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte**
Des scientifiques ont découvert qu’un virus provenant des pois à yeux noirs, appelé virus de la mosaïque du pois cajan (CPMV), peut activer le système immunitaire humain pour attaquer les cellules cancéreuses. Contrairement à beaucoup de virus, le CPMV n’infecte pas les cellules humaines mais réveille quand même les défenses du corps.

**Ce qui s’est passé**
Des chercheurs de l’Université de Californie à San Diego ont étudié le CPMV et ont découvert qu’il déclenche de fortes réactions immunitaires, en particulier en produisant des interférons—des protéines qui aident à organiser l’attaque contre les tumeurs. Ils ont comparé le CPMV à d’autres virus végétaux similaires qui n’ont pas cet effet, révélant ce qui rend le CPMV unique. Cette compréhension aide à expliquer pourquoi le CPMV peut agir comme une immunothérapie puissante et peu coûteuse.

**Impact**
Cette découverte signifie que nous pourrions avoir un traitement abordable utilisant un virus naturel de plante pour renforcer les capacités du corps à combattre le cancer. Étant donné que le CPMV est cultivé dans les plantes et stimule l’immunité sans infection, il offre un espoir d’accès élargi à l’immunothérapie contre le cancer, surtout dans les régions où les traitements coûteux sont difficiles à obtenir.

**Quelle est la prochaine étape**
Les chercheurs prévoient de lancer des essais cliniques pour tester la sécurité et l’efficacité des traitements à base de CPMV sur les humains. En cas de succès, cela pourrait mener à de nouvelles thérapies contre le cancer, abordables et bientôt disponibles.

**Résumé en une phrase**
Un virus des pois à yeux noirs libère la puissance du système immunitaire pour combattre le cancer, promettant un traitement efficace et économique.
articles.personality_title_es: Un virus vegetal entrena tu sistema inmunológico para combatir el cáncer
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto**
Científicos han descubierto que un virus de los frijoles ojo negro, llamado virus del mosaico del frijol caupí (CPMV), puede activar el sistema inmunológico humano para atacar las células cancerosas. A diferencia de muchos virus, el CPMV no infecta las células humanas pero despierta las defensas del cuerpo.

**Qué pasó**
Investigadores de la Universidad de California en San Diego estudiaron el CPMV y encontraron que provoca fuertes respuestas inmunitarias, especialmente al producir interferones, proteínas que ayudan a organizar el ataque a los tumores. Compararon el CPMV con virus vegetales similares que no tienen este efecto, descubriendo qué hace único al CPMV. Este conocimiento explica por qué el CPMV puede actuar como una inmunoterapia poderosa y de bajo costo.

**Impacto**
Este hallazgo significa que podríamos tener un tratamiento accesible que usa un virus natural de plantas para potenciar la capacidad del cuerpo de combatir el cáncer. Como el CPMV se cultiva en plantas y estimula la inmunidad sin infección, ofrece esperanza de un acceso más amplio a la inmunoterapia contra el cáncer, especialmente en lugares donde los tratamientos caros son difíciles de obtener.

**Próximo paso**
Los investigadores planean avanzar con ensayos clínicos para probar la seguridad y eficacia de tratamientos basados en CPMV en humanos. Si tienen éxito, esto podría conducir a nuevas terapias contra el cáncer, asequibles y disponibles pronto.

**Frase clave**
Un virus de los frijoles ojo negro está desbloqueando el poder del sistema inmunológico para combatir el cáncer, prometiendo una opción de tratamiento eficaz y económica.
articles.image_prompt: A detailed, warm painting of a vibrant cowpea plant with glowing virus-shaped particles gently interacting with symbolic immune cells represented as softly illuminated, friendly silhouettes surrounding and enveloping abstract cancer cell forms depicted as dark, fragmented shapes, all set against a simple, natural background of earthy tones and soft greens to convey healing and immune awakening.

articles.title: Millipedes make ants dizzy — and might soon treat human pain
articles.summary: Millipedes, often dismissed as creepy crawlies, may hold the secret to future painkillers and neurological drugs. Researchers at Virginia Tech discovered unique alkaloid compounds in the defensive secretions of a native millipede species. These complex molecules, which cause disorientation in ants, interact with human neuroreceptors linked to pain and cognition. By decoding these natural chemical defenses, scientists could open a new path toward innovative drug therapies, though challenges remain in producing the compounds at scale.
articles.content:
Millipedes get a bad rap -- their many legs put people off and could classify them as "creepy crawly." But these anthropods' secretions could hold the key to new drug discovery for the treatment of neurological diseases and pain.

Chemist Emily Mevers and her team recently discovered a new set of complex structures in millipede secretions that can modulate specific neuroreceptors in ant brains.

The newly discovered structures fall into a class of naturally occurring compounds called alkaloids. The Mevers team named them the andrognathanols and the andrognathines after the producing millipede, Andrognathus corticarius, found on Virginia Tech's Blacksburg campus in Stadium Woods. These discoveries were recently published in the Journal of the American Chemical Society.

A new compound discovery

Mevers specializes in leveraging the chemistry of underexplored ecological niches, in this case the millipede, in the name of drug discovery.

After collecting millipedes from under leaf litter and fallen branches in Stadium Woods, Mevers and team members used a variety of analytical tools to identify the compounds contained in the millipedes' defensive glands. They also learned that the millipedes release these compounds to ward off predators while also sharing their location with their kin.

Broader implications

Despite their pervasiveness, much about millipedes remains mysterious -- including their specific habitats, numbers, diets, behaviors, and chemistry. Mevers, in collaboration with millipede expert Paul Marek in the entomology department, is working to fill in some of these gaps and see if what they uncover could be useful for future medications.

Previously, Mevers and Marek examined a millipede native to the Pacific Northwest, Ishcnocybe plicata, and discovered that related alkaloids potently and selectively interact with a single neuroreceptor called Sigma-1. The interaction suggested that this family of compounds may have useful pharmacology potential for the treatment of pain and other neurological disorders.

The Mevers group discovered that the new alkaloids are actively secreted from the Hokie millipede when it is physically disturbed. The secretions cause disorientation in ants, a presumed natural predator. A subset of these compounds possesses similar interactions with the Sigma-1 neuroreceptor.

Moving toward drug development

With the newfound complex compounds in hand, the next step is finding people to actually make them in larger quantities and evaluate their biomedical applications.

"These compounds are quite complex, so they're going to take some time to synthesize in the lab," said Mevers.

Once larger quantities are available, Mevers will be able to better study their properties and potential in drug development.
articles.reasoning: The article highlights a promising scientific discovery involving millipede compounds that could lead to new painkillers and neurological drugs, representing a potential medical breakthrough that offers hope for improved treatments.
articles.personality_title: Millipedes' secret could lead to new pain relief
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context**
Millipedes are often seen as creepy bugs, but scientists have found something surprising in their defensive secretions. These secretions contain special chemicals that can affect the brains of ants.

**What happened**
Researchers at Virginia Tech, led by chemist Emily Mevers, discovered unique alkaloid compounds in a native millipede's secretions. Alkaloids are natural chemicals found in many plants and animals. These particular compounds make ants dizzy by interacting with their brain receptors.

**Impact**
The exciting part is that these same compounds can also affect human brain receptors linked to pain and thinking. This means they could become the basis for new medicines to treat pain and neurological conditions, offering hope for better treatments in the future.

**What's next step**
Scientists now aim to understand these compounds better and figure out how to produce them in larger amounts. This is important because making these complex natural chemicals on a big scale is challenging but necessary for developing new drugs.

**One-sentence takeaway**
What seemed like creepy millipedes might hold a natural key to relieving human pain and improving brain health.
articles.personality_title_fr: Le secret des mille-pattes pourrait conduire à de nouveaux antidouleurs
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte**
Les mille-pattes sont souvent vus comme des insectes effrayants, mais les scientifiques ont découvert quelque chose de surprenant dans leurs sécrétions défensives. Ces sécrétions contiennent des substances spéciales qui affectent le cerveau des fourmis.

**Ce qui s'est passé**
Des chercheurs de Virginia Tech, dirigés par la chimiste Emily Mevers, ont découvert des composés d'alcaloïdes uniques dans les sécrétions d'un mille-pattes local. Les alcaloïdes sont des substances naturelles présentes chez de nombreuses plantes et animaux. Ces composés rendent les fourmis étourdies en interagissant avec leurs récepteurs cérébraux.

**Impact**
La partie passionnante est que ces mêmes composés peuvent aussi affecter les récepteurs cérébraux humains liés à la douleur et à la cognition. Cela signifie qu'ils pourraient servir de base à de nouveaux médicaments pour traiter la douleur et les troubles neurologiques, offrant un espoir pour de meilleurs traitements.

**Prochaine étape**
Les scientifiques cherchent maintenant à mieux comprendre ces composés et à trouver comment les produire en plus grande quantité. C’est important car fabriquer ces substances naturelles complexes à grande échelle est un défi, mais nécessaire pour développer de nouveaux médicaments.

**Conclusion en une phrase**
Ce qui semblait être de simples mille-pattes effrayants pourrait détenir la clé naturelle pour soulager la douleur humaine et améliorer la santé cérébrale.
articles.personality_title_es: El secreto de los milpiés podría llevar a nuevos analgésicos
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto**
Los milpiés suelen verse como bichos inquietantes, pero los científicos han encontrado algo sorprendente en sus secreciones defensivas. Estas secreciones contienen químicos especiales que afectan el cerebro de las hormigas.

**Qué pasó**
Investigadores en Virginia Tech, dirigidos por la química Emily Mevers, descubrieron compuestos únicos de alcaloides en las secreciones de un milpiés nativo. Los alcaloides son sustancias naturales que se encuentran en muchas plantas y animales. Estos compuestos hacen que las hormigas se mareen al interactuar con sus receptores cerebrales.

**Impacto**
Lo emocionante es que estos mismos compuestos también pueden afectar los receptores cerebrales humanos relacionados con el dolor y la cognición. Esto significa que podrían ser la base para nuevos medicamentos para tratar el dolor y enfermedades neurológicas, ofreciendo esperanza para mejores tratamientos.

**Próximo paso**
Los científicos ahora buscan entender mejor estos compuestos y cómo producirlos en mayores cantidades. Esto es importante porque fabricar estos químicos naturales complejos a gran escala es un desafío, pero necesario para desarrollar nuevos medicamentos.

**Frase clave**
Lo que parecía ser un simple milpiés inquietante podría contener la clave natural para aliviar el dolor humano y mejorar la salud cerebral.
articles.image_prompt: A detailed, warm painting of a many-legged millipede releasing colorful, swirling chemical wisps that gently surround and disorient a group of small ants, set against a softly lit forest floor with fallen leaves and branches in simple natural tones.

articles.title: This fish-inspired suction cup can stick to your organs
articles.summary: Nature, Published online: 24 July 2025; doi:10.1038/d41586-025-02361-9The device could be swallowed for drug delivery or medical monitoring.
articles.content: Thank you for visiting nature.com. You are using a browser version with limited support for CSS. To obtain the best experience, we recommend you use a more up to date browser (or turn off compatibility mode in Internet Explorer). In the meantime, to ensure continued support, we are displaying the site without styles and JavaScript.
articles.reasoning: The article describes a medical device inspired by nature that can be swallowed for drug delivery or monitoring, representing a scientific and medical breakthrough with potential to improve patient care and health outcomes.
articles.personality_title: Fish-inspired suction cup offers new hope for medicine inside the body
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context**
Scientists have long looked to nature to solve tricky medical problems. One challenge is how to deliver medicine or monitor health inside the body without invasive procedures. Inspired by how certain fish use suction cups to stick firmly to surfaces, researchers have designed a new device that can be swallowed to attach safely inside organs.

**What happened**
A team has created a tiny suction cup modeled after fish anatomy that can cling to organs inside the body. This device can be swallowed like a pill and then attach itself inside the stomach or other organs. It can release medicine slowly or collect health data, reducing the need for needles or surgeries.

**Impact**
This breakthrough means patients may soon have a simpler, less painful way to receive treatment or monitoring. The suction cup's natural design helps it stick securely without harming tissue, improving comfort and safety. It could transform how doctors manage chronic diseases or deliver drugs.

**What's next step**
Researchers plan to test the device further in clinical trials to ensure it works well and is safe for humans. They also want to explore using it in different organs and with various medications. If successful, it could become a common tool in medicine.

**One-sentence takeaway**
Inspired by fish, a new swallowable suction cup could make internal medicine delivery and monitoring easier and safer for patients.
articles.personality_title_fr: Une ventouse inspirée des poissons offre un nouvel espoir pour la médecine interne
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte**
Les scientifiques s'inspirent souvent de la nature pour résoudre des problèmes médicaux complexes. Un défi consiste à administrer des médicaments ou surveiller la santé à l'intérieur du corps sans interventions invasives. Inspirée par la manière dont certains poissons utilisent des ventouses pour s'accrocher fermement, une équipe a conçu un nouvel appareil pouvant être avalé pour se fixer en toute sécurité dans les organes.

**Ce qui s'est passé**
Une équipe a créé une petite ventouse modelée d'après l'anatomie des poissons qui peut adhérer aux organes internes. Cet appareil peut être avalé comme une pilule, puis se fixer dans l'estomac ou d'autres organes. Il peut libérer lentement des médicaments ou recueillir des données de santé, réduisant le besoin d'aiguilles ou de chirurgies.

**Impact**
Cette avancée signifie que les patients pourront bientôt bénéficier d'un moyen plus simple et moins douloureux de recevoir des traitements ou une surveillance. Le design naturel de la ventouse lui permet de rester fixée sans abîmer les tissus, améliorant confort et sécurité. Cela pourrait transformer la gestion des maladies chroniques ou l'administration des médicaments.

**Prochaine étape**
Les chercheurs prévoient de tester davantage l'appareil lors d'essais cliniques pour garantir son efficacité et sa sécurité chez l'humain. Ils souhaitent aussi explorer son utilisation dans différents organes et avec divers médicaments. En cas de succès, il pourrait devenir un outil courant en médecine.

**En une phrase**
Inspirée des poissons, une nouvelle ventouse avalable pourrait faciliter et sécuriser la délivrance et la surveillance des soins médicaux internes pour les patients.
articles.personality_title_es: Una ventosa inspirada en peces ofrece nueva esperanza para la medicina interna
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto**
Los científicos suelen buscar en la naturaleza soluciones para problemas médicos difíciles. Un reto es cómo administrar medicamentos o monitorear la salud dentro del cuerpo sin procedimientos invasivos. Inspirados en cómo ciertos peces usan ventosas para adherirse firmemente, investigadores diseñaron un nuevo dispositivo que se puede tragar y que se adhiere de forma segura dentro de los órganos.

**Qué pasó**
Un equipo creó una pequeña ventosa basada en la anatomía de los peces que puede pegarse a órganos internos. Este dispositivo se puede tragar como una pastilla y se fija en el estómago u otros órganos. Puede liberar medicamentos lentamente o recopilar datos de salud, reduciendo la necesidad de agujas o cirugías.

**Impacto**
Este avance significa que pronto los pacientes podrán recibir tratamientos o monitoreo de forma más simple y menos dolorosa. El diseño natural de la ventosa ayuda a que se adhiera sin dañar tejidos, mejorando la comodidad y seguridad. Podría transformar la manera en que los médicos manejan enfermedades crónicas o administran medicamentos.

**Próximo paso**
Los investigadores planean hacer más pruebas clínicas para asegurar que el dispositivo funcione bien y sea seguro para humanos. También quieren probar su uso en diferentes órganos y con varios medicamentos. Si tiene éxito, podría convertirse en una herramienta común en la medicina.

**Mensaje clave en una frase**
Inspirada en peces, una nueva ventosa tragable podría facilitar y hacer más segura la administración y monitoreo médico interno para los pacientes.
articles.image_prompt: A detailed, warm-toned painting of a gentle octopus-inspired suction cup softly attaching to a glowing, stylized human organ floating in a serene underwater scene, using natural soft blues, gentle reds, and subtle creams with smooth, flowing lines that evoke care and innovation.
